You can accomplish this with symbolic links.

```powershell
New-Item -Path C:\mount -ItemType Directory
New-PSDrive -Name X -PSProvider FileSystem -Root C:\mount
New-Item -Name PowerShellGet -ItemType SymbolicLink -Value C:\Users\Thomas\Documents\PowerShell\Modules\PowerShellGet
New-Item -Name PSReadline -ItemType SymbolicLink -Value 'C:\Program Files\PowerShell\7\Modules\PSReadLine'
cd X:

X:\> Get-ChildItem
```

Thanks for your suggestion. Symbolic links has a issue for me: copy and delete can't effect original file.

So I then tried hard link solution:
```powershell
function Create-HardLink($Src, $Dst)
{
    Set-Location $ROOT
    if (!(Test-Path -Path $Src -PathType Container)) {
        throw [System.IO.FileNotFoundException] "ERR: invalid Src: $Src!"
    }
    Get-ChildItem $Src -File -Recurse -Exclude .git* | ForEach-Object {
        Set-Location $Src
        $l = Resolve-Path -Relative -Path $_
        Set-Location $ROOT
        $t = Resolve-Path -Relative -Path $_
        # link relative to codebase
        $l = $Dst + $l.TrimStart('.')
        # create hardlink
        New-Item -Force -ItemType HardLink -Path $l -Target $t > $null
    }
}
#
# Hlink $PKGS in $BASE
#
Create-HardLink $XAMI $BASE
Create-HardLink $PROJ $BASE

Set-Location $BASE
```
You know that, delete can't effect original file issue still exist on hard link. Besides, hard links can not do on folder, which take lots of time for GB size level of source files.
